adventure_overview: Scouts understand just how many things people with disabilities are able to do. You will discover some challenges people with disabilities face, and you will have the chance to try facing similar challenges yourself . A single activity can’t show you everything about life with a disability, but it can help you understand a little more about the ways a person with a disability is able to do things. Prior to any activity, use Scouting America SAFE Checklist to ensure the safety of all those involved. All participants in official Scouting America activities should become familiar with the Guide to Safe Scouting and applicable program literature or manuals.

requirements.text: Explore what it is to have a physical disability.

activities.name: Chair Ball
activities.description: Cub Scouts shoot baskets from a sitting position.

activities.name: Draw a Picture
activities.description: Cub Scouts will use tongs to draw a picture of their family.

activities.name: Mitten Hands
activities.description: Cub Scouts wear oversized gloves to complete simple tasks.

requirements.text: Explore what it is to have a visual impairment.

activities.name: Masked Artist
activities.description: Cub Scouts draw a picture then try to draw it again with their eyes covered.

activities.name: Service Dog Visit
activities.description: Cub Scouts learn about service dogs.

activities.name: Where is the ball?
activities.description: Cub Scouts toss a Nerf™ ball back and forth learning depth  perception .

requirements.text: Explore what it is to have a hearing loss.

activities.name: “Hello, my name is”
activities.description: Use American Sign Language to communicate a simple sentence that includes your name.

activities.name: Scout Law
activities.description: Cub Scouts try to speak to their  buddy  with a mouthful of marshmallows.

activities.name: Tele-What?
activities.description: Cub Scouts play “telephone” while ears are covered.

activities.name: Accessibility Walk Around
activities.description: Cub Scouts will take a walk around your meeting space to  identify  accommodations and lack of accommodations for people with disabilities.

activities.name: Out of Reach
activities.description: Cub Scouts sit on chairs to explore barriers to getting around.
